fr:mainmatter.html:p: For any i:\Delta ^{1}, we will write A^i for the function space {\mathopen {}\left (i=1\right )\mathclose {}}\to A.
Given a type A, let LA be the \Delta ^{1}-partial map classifier specified below:

We first claim that if A is a Segal type, then LA is also a Segal type; we must prove that the precomposition map {\mathopen {}\left [\epsilon ,LA\right ]\mathclose {}}\colon {\mathopen {}\left [\Delta ^{2},LA\right ]\mathclose {}}\to {\mathopen {}\left [\Lambda ^{2}_{1},LA\right ]\mathclose {}} is an equivalence.
We first give a more explicit computation of what a triangle in LA is.

By means of a version of the Phoa principle that I have not written down carefully yet, we should have an equivalence \Phi _2\colon {\mathopen {}\left [\Delta ^{2},\Delta ^{1}\right ]\mathclose {}}\to \Delta ^{3} sending h\colon \Delta ^{2}\to \Delta ^{1} to the following chain: \Phi _2 h:\equiv {\mathopen {}\left (h{\mathopen {}\left (0,0\right )\mathclose {}}\leq h{\mathopen {}\left (0,1\right )\mathclose {}}\leq h{\mathopen {}\left (1,1\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} Conversely, a chain {\mathopen {}\left (i\leq j \leq k\right )\mathclose {}}\colon \Delta ^{3} is identified with the map h\colon \Delta ^{2}\to \Delta ^{1} sending {\mathopen {}\left (l\leq m\right )\mathclose {}}:\Delta ^{2} to the connection i \lor {\mathopen {}\left (j\land l\right )\mathclose {}} \lor {\mathopen {}\left (k\land m\right )\mathclose {}}. That these operations are mutually inverse seems to be the essence of the Phoa principle.
